answers.answer: I had a friend who put on weight for reasons like that.Just as putting on weight took time, taking off the weight will take time.  I read a study that suggested you don't want to have the same calories every day; you want to go up and down a bit to keep your metabolism from shutting down.  Like throw in a 1500-calorie day now and then.Make sure you drink water and unsweetened green tea for beverages.  If dairy doesn't agree with you, try almond milk.  Dairy is a problem for many, many people, and I notice that MILK is on every low-calorie traditional diet.  It's hard to feel good if dairy is upsetting your system.Remember to make choices throughout your day that cause you to move instead of sit.  Don't use elevators or escalators - use the stairs. Jumping rope is very slimming.  Pilates can be done at home with very little equipment.  Put on your favorite music and dance for your warmup.  You won't even notice you are working your body and it elevates your mood.  Abandon any foods that have been an every day staple because you will tend to eat them without thinking and eat too much of it.  Load up on vegetables and eat fruit like apples every day.  Lots of colorful, unprocessed food.  Avoid breading and cook with olive oil when you can.  Remove skin from chicken.  Eat protein, including red meat, for the iron, but you only need a piece the size of a deck of cards.  Try an egg scrambled with any leftover vegetables you have.  You can use Go Veggie cheese shreds as a cheese alternative.

How did you arrive at the decision to eat 1200 calories/day?  That's not enough; your body will think it's starving and may hold onto fat, rather than letting it go.I calculated your Basic Metabolic Rate, which is the number of calories you need just to sustain life.  This is based on they weight, height and age you posted above.  Based on those numbers, your Basic Metabolic Rate is around 1800 calories/day; that's to keep your heart beating, kidneys, brain, digestions and other organs functioning.In order to lose weight, you need to either drop about 500 calories/day from that, making it 1300 calories/day, or it's easier to drop 250 calories and use up an extra 250 calories every day.  This would help you lose 1 pound/week.I agree that it's important to vary your calories, as well as your exercise.  It's also a good idea to keep a food diary, showing what you ate, how many calories, etc.  Often, we tend to eat more than we think we are; writing it down, or tracking it, keeps it all in perspective.  MedHelp has a good food diary, and there are also other ones available.  Many can be synced to your mobile device, so you can even track calories on the go.  I know of one, that even lets you scan the bar code and looks it up in the database, so you don't have to spend time searching.You don't  have to do a lot of exercise; the key is to do it regularly.

High cholesterol is a sign of possible hypothyroidism.  High insulin indicates insulin resistance, which is also known as pre-diabetes.Both hypothyroidism and insulin resistance cause weight gain/inability to lose.  You should get some thyroid tests done.  You need TSH, Free T3 and Free T4.
